title: 115_s2079
content: The "Airline Accountability Act" promotes economic security and workplace accountability. The Administrator of the General Services Administration requires air carriers to disclose any labor law violations in the past 3 years to be eligible for the City Pair Program. The laws and regulations that air carriers must comply with to be eligible for the City Pair Program include the National Labor Relations Act, the Davis-Bacon Act, the Service Contract Act, Executive Order 11246, the Rehabilitation Act, the Family and Medical Leave Act, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. The Administrator of the General Services Administration requires air carriers in the City Pair Program to include in subcontracts a disclosure requirement for any administrative merits determination, arbitral award, or civil judgment. The Secretary of Labor defines civil judgments against subcontractors for labor law violations within a 3-year period. The Secretary is available for consultation with air carriers to assess labor compliance. The Secretary also allows air carriers to report corrective measures annually. The Secretary of Labor prepares a list of ineligible air carriers for the City Pair Program based on labor law violations. Air carriers can negotiate corrective measures to avoid being placed on the list. The Secretary of Labor prepares a list of ineligible air carriers for the City Pair Program based on labor law violations. The Administrator of the General Services Administration will not solicit contracts from carriers on the list for Federal employee air travel programs. The requirements do not apply to contracts solicited within 2 years prior to the date. Contracts solicited prior to 2 years after the enactment of this Act are exempt from the requirements regarding ineligible air carriers for the City Pair Program based on labor law violations.
